doc.title: Cash spend on development steps up
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.2 普通个人版/Barclays/CD Projekt Cash spend on development steps upCD Projekt Cash spend on development steps up_2025-08-29

passages.text: 2Q25 P&L results were modestly ahead of Barclays and more notably above consensus (on profit). But cash spend on development costs stepped up vs 1Q25 and is expected to increase again next quarter. So we have reduced FCF this year and next year. Nothing in the short term moves the DCF needle much.

We had already factored in that sales of units for the new Switch 2 console were heavily weighted to Nintendo's own titles, while benefits from the inclusion of Cyberpunk 2077 in PlayStation Plus do not come in until Q3. So we were not surprised that Q2 revenues dipped vs Q1, but we slightly exaggerated the effect and they came in \(5\% /6\%\) higher than us on 2Q25 revenue/operating profit. The beat on operating profit was notably higher vs consensus. While it is always good to see a beat on P&L forecasts, higher expenditure on development projects sounds a more negative note. While we and consensus do not model this number for 2Q25, the PLN142m was a clear step- up vs 1Q25 at PLN100m - and management noted it would be higher in 3Q25 than in 2Q25. So we have raised our FY25 number from PLN360m to PLN540m, driving an \(8\%\) reduction in FCF this year and \(18\%\) next year. FCF gives the clearest picture of the business, given the big lag between spend on developers and the amortisation of those costs when a game is released. But in the context of our DCF, changes to FCF in 2025 and 2026 are not significant, given much higher numbers expected in launch years beyond 2026. We make only small changes to our forecasts and move our DCF- driven price target up to PLN135. We remain Underweight.

Switch 2 benefits - we assume more to come in Q3 and Q4: Management flagged that while Cyberpunk 2077 has been one of the best- selling third- party (non- Nintendo) games on the Switch 2, 1) Nintendo's first- party titles have been dominating sales and 2) \(70\%\) of the Cyberpunk 2077 game sold for Switch 2 so far have been physical (cartridges) and those have a lower economic cost of CD Projekt. So there has not been a notable boost in Q2. We expect some improvements there as a) digital units start to take over from physical a little more, and b) particularly around the holiday season there may be more interest in third- party games for the Switch 2.
More "expenditure on development projects" than we expected: In 2Q25, CD Projekt spent PLN142m on "expenditure on development projects", which is essentially spend on developers
This research report has been prepared in whole or in part by equity research analysts based outside the US who are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA.

working on games that have yet to be released (the largest part of CD Projekt's cost base right now). We do not model H1 cash flow but this was ahead of what we would have expected. They also noted that this should increase again in Q3. We assume that Q4 is at the same level as Q3, which means that we have just under PLN300m in 2H25, taking our FY25 number to PLN540m from PLN360m previously. We think this is also more than consensus has, although we cannot pick out that exact number on Bloomberg. In the context of our DCF, lower FCF (as a result of this change) in 2025 and 2026 is not that meaningful, given high amounts of FCF in the years beyond 2026. But in the short term this is a notable reduction in FCF.

Price Target **PLN 135.00**
**Why UNDERWEIGHT?**

CD Projekt's shares have been boosted by excitement around the launch of Phantom Liberty. The game has been successful but next catalysts appear a long way off. We think the valuation gap between CD Projekt and other video game players should close further, so we expect a further derating.
**Upside case** **PLN 270.00**We use a "fair value" upside scenario based on our FY26E 'recovery EPS' and what we believe to be fair value P/E.

**Downside case** **PLN 130.00**Our downside is based on a "recession" P/E (average of what happened in the last two recessions excluding the punctual outlier data) applied to our base-case recession scenario EPS (explained in Media Watch 35).
Upside/Downside scenarios

CD Projekt delivered PLN216.7m of revenue for 2Q25, \(5\%\) ahead of us and Bloomberg median consensus. Operating profit was PLN72.5m, again \(6\%\) ahead of us and \(34\%\) ahead of Bloomberg consensus. The operating profit margins were \(33.4\%\) , broadly in line with ours. They noted that revenues continue to be dominated by Cyberpunk 2077 together with its Phantom Liberty expansion.
Below operating profit, net profit was PLN69m, c. \(14\%\) ahead of us, with higher than expected interest income partially offset by higher tax rate at \(21.5\%\) vs our \(18.8\%\) .
We show 2Q25 results in the table below and discuss the highlights beneath:
FIGURE 1. CD Projekt 2Q25 results vs Barclays and Bloomberg consensus

Source: Company information; Barclays Research estimates

- They noted that, at the beginning of 2Q25 the Cyberpunk 2 development team progressed to the game's preproduction phase (already flagged at Q1).- In 2Q25, they expanded the availability of Cyberpunk 2077 to new platforms: to Nintendo Switch on 5 June and then to Mac devices on 17 July.- The base edition of the game is also available in the PlayStation Plus catalogue within the Extra and Premium membership tiers since July.- For game development costs, they noted that the most significant expenditure on development projects were related to The Witcher 4, Cyberpunk 2 and Sirius projects which were in the development phase.

Below we summarise the updates about the future pipeline provided yesterday and in the previous results. They have not provided any timeline for the projects, but we have put these in the order that they are likely to come to market:

- Project Polaris 
-Among the new games, Polaris, the first instalment of the new Witcher trilogy (so The Witcher 4), is the furthest along in development, with 444 people working on the game vs 422 as of 30 April 2025. They do not expect significant changes to team size and

the game is currently in the production phase. In 4Q24 results, management had noted that they did not expect the game to be released before the end of 2026, but did not comment on when it would be released.

- Project Sirius 
- The game is currently in the pre-production phase, being developed by The Molasses Flood. Headcount was 51, slightly higher than 48 people in April 2025. In 4Q24 they had noted they will merge The Molasses Flood team with CD Projekt Red to better align the scope and direction of the project. But this has no bearing on any of their other teams or the speed of other projects.

- Canis Majoris 
- It is a remake of The Witcher, developed by Fool's Theory (an independent developer). The project is currently in the conceptual phase.

- Cyberpunk 2 
- They noted that Cyberpunk 2 (the next large game set in the Cyberpunk universe) has completed its concept stage and has progressed to preproduction in early 2Q25. There are currently 116 people working on the project, up from 96 in April 2025.

- Project Hadar 
- This is in an IP concept phase. There are currently 22 people working on the project, vs 19 in April 2025. They are currently carrying out internal conceptual work for the game.

Due to the small beat vs our forecasts for 2Q25, we have increased our revenue and operating profit forecasts modestly for 2025 and 2026. But this is more than offset at the FCF level by higher expenditure on development projects.

In 2Q25, this reached PLN142m on "expenditure on development projects", a clear step up vs PLN100m in 1Q25. We do not model H1 cash flow, but this was ahead of what we would have expected. They also noted that this should increase again in Q3.

We assume that Q4 is at the same level as Q3, which means that we have just under PLN300m in 2H25, taking our FY25 number to PLN540m from PLN360m previously. We think this is also more than consensus had pre- results, although we cannot pick out that exact number on Bloomberg.

In the context of our DCF, lower FCF (as a result of this change) in 2025 and 2026 is not that meaningful, given high amounts of FCF in the years beyond 2026. But in the short term this is a notable reduction in FCF.

Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.

**Valuation** **Methodology:** We use a DCF to drive our price target, modelling out-unlevered FCF to 2030 based on our game launch assumptions and then we use a 3% terminal growth rate and a 10% WACC. We also ascribe a corporate governance discount of 5%.

**Risks** **which** **May** **Impede** **the** **Achievement** **of** **the** **Barclays** **Research** **Valuation** **and** **Price** **Target:** Risks on the upside are 1) Cyberpunk 2077, The Witcher and other back catalogue games continue to sell well beyond 2024 2) The Witcher 4 gets released earlier than expected and sells more units than expected.
